31.text:
Thank you, Arminka, Baroness Helic, for that
incredible, personal story. From Bosnia to

40.text:
Britain, from arriving here as a refugee to
serving the public in government and in the

46.text:
House of Lords, your story is an inspiration
to us all. So, on behalf of everybody here

54.text:
today, thank you.
Before I begin, I’m sure I speak for everyone

66.text:
at Conference when I say that our thoughts
and prayers are with the family, friends and

73.text:
colleagues of Police Constable David Phillips
who was killed in the line of duty in the

80.text:
small hours of yesterday morning. PC Phillips,
who served with Merseyside Police, leaves

87.text:
behind a loving wife, Jennifer, and two young
daughters, Abigail and Sophie.

95.text:
His death serves as a reminder of the very
real dangers our police officers face, day

102.text:
in, day out.
Ten days ago I attended the National Police

108.text:
Memorial Day service where we remember all
police officers who have died in service to

114.text:
the public. The police put themselves in harm’s
way to keep us all safe, dealing with dangerous

121.text:
situations and taking risks so that that we
can live our lives safely and securely.

129.text:
I know that officers across the country – particularly
here in the North West of England – and

135.text:
the members of the public they serve have
been deeply saddened by yesterday’s news

139.text:
– and humbled by the bravery that officers
such as PC Phillips show.

145.text: We owe them all our gratitude.

149.text:
The conflict in Syria
2,000 miles away, in towns and cities across

165.text:
Syria, eleven million men, women and children
have been forced from their homes. More than

173.text:
four million have become refugees. And nearly
a quarter of a million have been killed.

180.text:
More than 600,000 Syrians are taking refuge
in Jordan, a country that before the conflict

187.text:
had a population of little more than six million.
There are more than one million finding respite

193.text:
in Lebanon, which previously had a population
of just over four million. By the end of the

199.text:
year, the United Nations believes there will
be a further 1.7 million Syrian refugees in

206.text:
Turkey.
These people are fleeing a civil war that

211.text:
exceeds even the other conflicts of the Middle
East in its barbarism, brutality and bloodshed.

218.text:
Bashar al Assad’s forces are committing
war crimes on an industrial scale, deliberately

226.text:
targeting civilians and poisoning their own
citizens with chemical weapons. ISIL – the

232.text:
so-called Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant
– is engaged in a programme of ethnic cleansing,

239.text:
mass murder of enemy soldiers, systematised
rape and sexual violence, kidnappings and

246.text:
murder.
And the other players in this appalling civil

250.text:
war include Hezbollah, Al Nusra Front – a
jihadist group affiliated to Al Qaeda – and

257.text:
several other jihadist militias.
These militias in turn are often backed by

263.text:
powerful foreign sponsors, and the forces
of Bashar al Assad are supported by Iran and

269.text:
Russia – whose warplanes are engaged in
airstrikes against civilians and anti-government

275.text:
fighters.
So it is too simplistic to say that there

280.text:
is a single intervention which will bring
a sudden end to the fighting. There is no

285.text:
easy solution to the civil war in Syria, and
we must learn the lessons of the past.

291.text:
But that does not mean Britain should do nothing.
We must work to get the states that sponsor

297.text:
the different armies and militias around the
negotiating table. We must do what we can

302.text:
to support friendly states and moderate elements
within other states in the region. And – because

308.text:
of the clear threat they pose to Britain’s
national security – we must take action

314.text:
against ISIL not just in Iraq but in Syria
too.

327.text:
To those who question the morality of RAF
strikes against terrorists in Syria – and

333.text:
we recently heard those opinions expressed
in Parliament – I say these people have

339.text:
taken the conscious decision to make themselves
our enemies. They plan to attack our country

347.text:
and kill our citizens. And they need to know
– even if they are British nationals – that

354.text:
if they plan to do harm to this country, if
they want to take the lives of British citizens,

361.text:
we will make sure that they have no place
to hide.

379.text:
We must also do everything possible to alleviate
the suffering of the Syrian people. Since

385.text:
the start of the war we’ve granted asylum
to more than 5,000 Syrians in Britain. We’ve

391.text:
created a resettlement scheme to find – working
with the UN – the most vulnerable refugees

397.text:
in the region and bring them to our country.
And as the Prime Minister announced last month,

402.text:
we will take in 20,000 Syrian refugees over
the course of this Parliament – a decision

409.text:
not imposed on us by Europe, but a decision
taken by Britain, an independent sovereign

415.text:
country.
But the best way of helping the most people

428.text:
is not by bringing relatively small numbers
of refugees to this country, but by working

433.text:
with the vast numbers who remain in the region.
That’s why Britain is spending £1 billion

440.text:
in and around Syria on humanitarian aid, caring
for refugees and helping the governments of

445.text:
Lebanon, Jordan and Turkey to cope with the
huge numbers of refugees they’ve received.

451.text:
After the United States, Britain is the biggest
donor country in the region, and no European

457.text:
country has come close to matching the amount
we’re spending there.

463.text:
Thanks to our help, hungry families are getting
food, thirsty people are getting clean water,

469.text:
and children who have been orphaned or separated
from their parents are getting help. This

474.text:
is more than Britain has ever spent in response
to a humanitarian disaster – and we should

479.text:
be immensely proud of the difference we are
making.

492.text:
The migration debate
The crisis in Syria sparked a debate this

495.text:
summer not just about foreign policy and military
intervention but about refugees and immigration.

504.text:
With more than 430,000 migrants having reached
Europe by sea this year, the countries of

510.text:
Europe resurrecting borders they’d once
removed, and thousands of people in Calais

515.text:
trying to reach Britain illegally, some people
have argued that we’re on the verge of a

520.text:
‘great age of migration’, in which national
governments are powerless to resist huge numbers

525.text:
of people, travelling the world in search
of a better life.

530.text:
But people on both extremes of the debate
– from the anti-immigration far right to

535.text:
the open-borders liberal left – conflate
refugees in desperate need of help with economic

543.text:
migrants who simply want to live in a more
prosperous society. Their desire for a better

549.text:
life is perfectly understandable, but their
circumstances are not nearly the same as those

556.text:
of the people fleeing their homelands in fear
of their lives. There are millions of people

563.text:
in poorer countries who would love to live
in Britain, and there is a limit to the amount

569.text:
of immigration any country can and should
take. While we must fulfil our moral duty

585.text:
to help people in desperate need, we must
also have an immigration system that allows

591.text:
us to control who comes to our country.
Because when immigration is too high, when

598.text:
the pace of change is too fast, it’s impossible
to build a cohesive society. It’s difficult

605.text:
for schools and hospitals and core infrastructure
like housing and transport to cope. And we

611.text:
know that for people in low-paid jobs, wages
are forced down even further while some people

617.text:
are forced out of work altogether.
Now I know there are some people who say,

629.text:
yes there are costs of immigration, but the
answer is to manage the consequences, not

634.text:
reduce the numbers. But not all of the consequences
can be managed, and doing so for many of them

641.text:
comes at a high price. We need to build 210,000
new homes every year to deal with rising demand.

650.text:
We need to find 900,000 new school places
by 2024. And there are thousands of people

657.text:
who have been forced out of the labour market,
still unable to find a job.

662.text:
But even if we could manage all the consequences
of mass immigration, Britain does not need

668.text:
net migration in the hundreds of thousands
every year. Of course, immigrants plug skills

674.text:
shortages and it’s right that we should
try to attract the best talent in the world,

681.text:
but not every person coming to Britain right
now is a skilled electrician, engineer or

687.text:
doctor. The evidence – from the OECD, the
House of Lords Economic Affairs Committee

693.text:
and many academics – shows that while there
are benefits of selective and controlled immigration,

700.text:
at best the net economic and fiscal effect
of high immigration is close to zero. So there

708.text:
is no case, in the national interest, for
immigration of the scale we have experienced

713.text:
over the last decade.
Neither is it true that, in the modern world,

727.text:
immigration is no longer possible to control.
The experience of the last five years is that

732.text:
where the Government has the political will
to reduce immigration, it can do so. We rooted

738.text:
out abuse of the student visa system, and
the numbers went down. We reformed family

743.text:
visas, and the numbers went down. We capped
economic migration from outside the EU, and

750.text:
– despite the growing economy – the numbers
remained stable. Overall, after my first two

756.text:
years as Home Secretary, net migration – which
had reached 320,000 in 2005 – fell to 154,000.

765.text:
Since then, however, the numbers have doubled
once more. One of the reasons is student visas.

772.text:
And let me be clear about students.
We welcome students coming to study. But the

780.text:
fact is, too many of them are not returning
home as soon as their visa runs out. If they

787.text:
have a graduate job, that is fine. If not,
they must return home. So I don’t care what

795.text:
the university lobbyists say: the rules must
be enforced. Students, yes; over-stayers,

801.text:
no. And the universities must make this happen.
Another reason is European migration. For

817.text:
years, net migration from within the EU was
balanced. The number of people coming to the

822.text:
UK was matched by the number of Brits and
Europeans moving to other EU countries. In

829.text:
recent years, the figures have become badly
unbalanced – partly because our growing

833.text:
economy is creating huge numbers of jobs.
The numbers coming from Europe are unsustainable

840.text:
and the rules have to change. At the moment,
for example, workers coming to the UK on very

847.text:
low salaries can claim over £10,000 on top
of their salary in benefits – which makes

854.text:
the UK a hugely attractive destination. This
is not good for us – or for the countries

861.text:
those people are leaving.
That is why the PM is right to target the

867.text:
amount we pay in benefits for those coming
to the UK to work, and put these arrangements

873.text:
on a sensible basis.
So those are the main reasons why net migration

879.text:
is still too high. But the trouble is, other
changes mean that without the right policies

886.text:
it’s going to get even harder to keep the
numbers down. Modern forms of communication,

891.text:
cheaper international travel, and the increase
in relative prosperity for many people in

896.text:
the developing world mean that larger numbers
of people are more mobile than ever before.

902.text:
And this is compounded by several other factors.
For years, despite its many other flaws and

909.text:
its criminal leadership, Libya was known as
Europe’s ‘forward border’. British immigration

915.text:
officials worked there with their European
and Libyan counterparts to stop illegal immigration

920.text:
from Africa at its source. Now the criminal
gangs that smuggle people into Europe have

926.text:
been able to work unimpeded. Free movement
rules don’t just mean European nationals

933.text:
have the right to reside in Britain, they
now mean anybody who has married a European

937.text:
can come here almost without condition. And
Schengen – the agreement that abolished

944.text:
borders between EU states apart from Britain
and Ireland – means that once a migrant

948.text:
arrives in a country with weak border controls,
like Greece, they can make their way across

954.text:
Europe and into Germany, or up to the British
border at Calais, without checks. Many of

961.text:
those people will eventually get EU citizenship
and the free movement rights that come with

966.text:
it.
Even actions taken with the best of intentions

972.text:
have consequences. When the German Government,
motivated by compassion and decency, said

979.text:
they expected to receive 800,000 asylum seekers
this year, it prompted hundreds of thousands

985.text:
of people to try to get to Germany. Some of
these people were refugees coming directly

991.text:
from Syria or the camps in Jordan, Turkey
and Lebanon, but many – in fact, up to half

997.text:
of them – were migrants from other parts
of the world.

1001.text:
So reducing and controlling immigration is
getting harder, but that’s no reason to

1007.text:
give up. As our manifesto said, ‘we must
work to control immigration and put Britain

1014.text:
first’.
We have to do this for the sake of our society

1029.text:
and our public services – and for the sake
of the people whose wages are cut, and whose

1033.text:
job security is reduced, when immigration
is too high.

1036.text:
A new plan for asylum
And there’s another reason. Without controlled

1043.text:
immigration, there will be less public support
for taking in refugees. And – while we cannot

1049.text:
solve every problem in every corner of the
world by granting asylum to everybody in difficulty

1054.text:
– we do have a moral duty to help people
in need. We should play our part.

1061.text:
The trouble is, the asylum system was abused
for years. Under Labour it was just another

1068.text:
way of getting here to work. In 2002, there
were more than 84,000 applications for asylum.

1076.text:
This alone constituted 49 per cent of net
migration to Britain. And we ended up with

1083.text:
a backlog of nearly half a million cases.
We now have much more control in the system

1089.text:
than we’ve had for a long time – even
with Syria, there were just over 25,000 applications

1094.text:
last year, which was only eight per cent of
net migration – but in truth the whole way

1099.text:
in which we manage asylum is not right for
the modern world.

1103.text:
The system is geared towards helping those
most able to access it, and sometimes manipulate

1109.text:
it, for their own ends – those who are young
enough, fit enough, and have the resources

1114.text:
to get to Britain. But that means support
is too often denied to the most vulnerable,

1119.text:
and those most in need of our help.
At the moment, the main way people claim asylum

1125.text:
here is when they’re already in Britain.
That fails on three counts. First, it encourages

1130.text:
vulnerable people to take dangerous and illegal
journeys to get here, often by putting themselves

1136.text:
at the mercy of gangs of human traffickers
and people smugglers. Second, instead of helping

1142.text:
those in greatest need, it rewards the wealthiest,
the luckiest and the strongest. Three quarters

1147.text:
of asylum seekers in Britain are men and the
vast majority are in their twenties. And third,

1155.text:
it means people abuse the system by claiming
asylum when their visa ends or by making spurious

1162.text:
legal appeals to stay in the country for as
long as possible. More than half of all asylum

1168.text:
claims fail, and three quarters of people
denied asylum appeal their decision in the

1173.text:
courts.
This is not something that Britain alone needs

1176.text:
to address. In France, we’ve seen thousands
of people – mainly young men, from a variety

1181.text:
of countries – who have travelled unchecked
across Europe before amassing in Calais with

1185.text:
the hope of getting to Britain. In Germany,
generous rules mean that more than forty per

1190.text:
cent of people who seek asylum are from countries
in the Balkans which thankfully have not seen

1195.text:
conflict for twenty years. Since the crisis
in Syria began, 291,000 Syrians have claimed

1202.text:
asylum across Europe as a whole. But even
more – 398,000 people in total – claimed

1208.text:
asylum from safe countries in the Western
Balkans.

1212.text:
These problems have led some people to say
we need a new approach, a new European approach

1217.text:
that would involve a common immigration and
asylum policy. To those people, I have a very

1224.text:
clear answer. Not in a thousand years. We’re
not seeking to regain control of our borders

1241.text:
with one hand, only to give it away with the
other.

1245.text:
So to those who say we should do more, I say
look at what Britain is doing for Syrians

1249.text:
at home and in the Middle East, look at the
contributions of other European countries,

1254.text:
and think again. To those who say Europe is
about to be overwhelmed by refugees, I say

1261.text:
less than twenty per cent of Europe’s asylum
seekers are from Syria, while nearly thirty

1265.text:
per cent are from the Balkans. To those who
say the answer to this challenge is more integration,

1271.text:
I say look at the countries in Europe who
signed up to Schengen but are now putting

1275.text:
up fences and re-establishing border checks.
To those who say the problem is too great

1282.text:
for nation states to resolve themselves, I
say it can only be resolved by nation states

1289.text:
taking responsibility themselves – and protecting
their own national borders.

1296.text:
So we don’t need a common European asylum
policy. But we do need a new British approach

1308.text:
and we do need a new international approach
with nation states working together. An approach

1314.text:
that combines hard-headed common sense with
warm-hearted compassion. An approach with

1321.text:
strict new rules for people who abuse the
system in Britain, and greater generosity

1326.text:
for people in parts of the world where we
know they need our help.

1331.text:
So, wherever possible, I want to offer asylum
and refuge to people in parts of the world

1336.text:
affected by conflict and oppression, rather
than to those who have made it to Britain.

1342.text:
I want us to work to reduce the asylum claims
made in Britain, and as we do so increase

1347.text:
the number of people we help in the most troubled
regions.

1352.text:
So we’ll introduce strengthened ‘safe
return reviews’ – so when a refugee’s

1357.text:
temporary stay of protection in the UK comes
to an end, or if there is a clear improvement

1362.text:
in the conditions of their own country, we
will review their need for protection. If

1368.text:
their reason for asylum no longer stands and
it is now safe for them to return, we will

1373.text:
seek to return them to their home country
rather than offer settlement here in Britain.

1378.text:
For the first time we’ll distinguish between
vulnerable people resettled from their region

1385.text:
and those who claim asylum after abusing the
visa system or having travelled to get here

1390.text:
through safe countries. If you’ve spurned
the chance to seek protection elsewhere – but

1396.text:
we cannot return you to that safe country
and you still need refuge – you’ll get

1401.text:
the minimum stay of protection and you won’t
have an automatic right to settle here. But

1407.text:
for those who really need it, we will offer
a longer stay of protection. Humane for those

1413.text:
who need our help, tough on those who abuse
it.

1421.text:
Sometimes, it isn’t the individual person
who holds up their deportation but their home

1430.text:
country’s government. In the absence of
specific identification documents – which

1435.text:
are often destroyed by the individual themselves
– some countries deny the nationality of

1440.text:
their citizen and refuse to take them back.
This happens in thousands of cases every year.

1446.text:
So from now on, we will use alternative documentation
– copies of which exist for anybody who

1451.text:
first entered the country on a legal, biometric
visa – as proof of the individual’s identity.

1458.text:
If any foreign governments refuse to recognise
these documents – which, in many cases,

1463.text:
they helped to produce in the first place
– we will take retaliatory measures. The

1469.text:
message will be clear – if other governments
don’t play by the rules, there will be consequences.

1476.text:
We will also – for the first time – invoke
what is known as the ‘Spanish Protocol’

1482.text:
of the Amsterdam Treaty, which allows EU member
states to treat any asylum claim by a citizen

1489.text:
of another EU country as automatically inadmissible.
It sounds crazy, but in the last five years,

1498.text:
there have been 551 asylum claims in Britain
from people from other EU countries – like

1506.text:
Poland and Spain. All but a handful were turned
down – but they cost over £4 million to

1514.text:
the British taxpayer. So we will end this
absurdity, creating space in our asylum system

1520.text:
to help people who really need our protection
– and saving taxpayers’ money.

1532.text:
In the longer term, I want to work with other
countries in Europe, and the United Nations,

1537.text:
to review the international legal definitions
of asylum and refugee status. Because there

1543.text:
is a huge difference between a young Syrian
family fleeing the tyranny of ISIL or Assad,

1550.text:
and a student who claims asylum once he has
been discovered overstaying his visa, or a

1556.text:
foreign criminal about to be sent to a prison
in his own country.

1561.text:
By taking a tougher approach to those who
do not need our help, we can give more support

1566.text:
to vulnerable people who are in real and urgent
need of our protection. So, next year, we

1572.text:
will publish this country’s first ever annual
asylum strategy, which will set out where

1577.text:
our help will be targeted – and how we will
crack down on those who abuse it.

1583.text:
In Britain, we will make sure that councils
get the help they need to deal with people

1587.text:
as they arrive. I know the whole country was
proud of the generosity of spirit shown by

1593.text:
the British businesses and families who offered
to shelter Syrian refugees in their own properties

1599.text:
this summer. So to help turn these acts of
humanity into reality, we’ll establish a

1605.text:
register of people and organisations that
can provide houses for the settlement of refugees.

1611.text:
We’ll develop a community sponsorship scheme,
like those in Canada and Australia, to allow

1616.text:
individuals, charities, faith groups, churches
and businesses to support refugees directly.

1623.text:
And we’ll use the aid budget and other funds
to take the pressure off local services and

1628.text:
make sure councils have the money they need.
People who apply for asylum in the UK will

1634.text:
be processed quickly and fairly. If they are
approved, they will be granted our protection

1640.text:
for the length of time that their home country
remains unsafe for them to return. But if

1645.text:
they are not approved, they must be made to
leave the country quickly – and that’s

1649.text:
exactly what our new Immigration Bill will
do.

1652.text:
What I’m proposing is a deal: the fewer
people there are who wrongly claim asylum

1660.text:
in Britain, the more generous we can be in
helping the most vulnerable people in the

1665.text:
world’s most dangerous places. And my message
to the immigration campaigners and human rights

1672.text:
lawyers is this: you can play your part in
making this happen – or you can try to frustrate

1679.text:
it. But if you choose to frustrate it, you
will have to live with the knowledge that

1684.text:
you are depriving people in genuine need of
the sanctuary our country can offer. There

1690.text:
are people who need our help, and there are
people who are abusing our goodwill – and

1695.text:
I know whose side I’m on.
A beacon of hope

1708.text:
We will not be able to solve all the world’s
problems, we won’t be able to help every

1712.text:
single person in need, and we won’t be able
to offer refuge to everybody who needs it.

1718.text:
But with a new approach to asylum, with the
massive humanitarian support we are already

1722.text:
providing in Syria and its neighbouring states,
and with the right kind of diplomatic leadership,

1729.text:
Britain can play a leading part in alleviating
the suffering of the Syrian people and others

1734.text:
like them around the world.
But to deliver this new approach to asylum,

1740.text:
we need to distinguish carefully between economic
migrants and genuine refugees. We have to

1747.text:
be a country in control, stricter with people
who try to abuse the system so that our help

1753.text:
is not denied to those who need it.
We will also need to have more control of

1759.text:
immigration overall. It’s often said – usually
by advocates of open-door immigration – that

1766.text:
Britain is by definition a country of immigrants.
In fact, compared to the countries of the

1771.text:
New World and compared to the countries of
Europe with their shifting land borders, we

1776.text:
have until recently always been a country
of remarkable population stability. The people

1782.text:
who have moved here down the generations have
played a massive part in making this country

1788.text:
what it is – but we need our immigration
system to continue that British tradition

1795.text:
of gradual, moderate, sensible change.
That is how, as a country, we have always

1807.text:
been able to show great responsibility to
the people who need our help in their darkest

1814.text:
moments: the country that accepted the Huguenot
Protestant refugees from France, the Jews

1820.text:
escaping the pogroms of Russia and the persecution
of the Nazis, the Asians of Uganda expelled

1827.text:
by Idi Amin.
We have a proud history of relieving the distressed

1833.text:
and helping the vulnerable – whether it’s
through our military, our diplomacy, our humanitarian

1839.text:
work or our support for refugees, let us continue
this tradition. Let Britain stand up for the

1848.text:
displaced, the persecuted and the oppressed.
For the people who need our help and protection

1856.text: the most, let Britain be a beacon of hope.
